titleStmt.title: Describing the death
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: The handwriting and ink of this manuscript are very similar to the handwriting and ink on the back, which features draft lines of the poem that would eventually be titled "Song of Myself." The date of both is therefore likely before or early in 1855.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Walt Whitman. Holograph Manuscript Fragments Assembled by Dr. Richard Maurice Bucke.
bibl.orgName: The Oscar Lion Papers, 1914–1955, New York Public Library, New York, N.Y.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
On the back of this leaf are poetic lines that were used in revised form in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, in the poem that was eventually titled "Song of Myself."

revisionDesc.change: revised repository information in header; made minor revisions to transcription and encoding
metadata extracted and transformed from EAD file

body.ab: Describing the death of nine seven brothers and their parents——who can say that those who were least least most lucky who died the earliest, or under the most appalingappalling circumstances? Or that those were luckiest who made the most wealth, and lived the longest stretch of mortality?
